crops.description: A collection of locally grown vegetable seeds, collected at Merzifon; introduced for the use of Department specialists working in the north-central part of the United States. Flowering orka

crops.name_of_crop: Adenium obesum (Forsk.) Roem. and Schult. Apocynaceae
crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Cuttings collected in Hope Garden, Kingston. A slow-growing shrub, not over 3 feet high, native to the dry regions of Arabia and named after the desert port of Aden. The gorgeous rose-pink to white flowers are 3 inches across and remind one of enormous oleander blossoms. The flowers are borne so abundantly that they cover the entire shrub.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plants collected in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. This gorgeous red-flowered tree is considered by some to be the most beautiful of all the flowering trees. It is native to the Malay Peninsula, and was named after Lady Amherst.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Seeds collected in Kingston.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Purchased in the market at Kingston.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Seeds bought in the public market at Kingston.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plants purchased in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. A spiny pinnate-leaved palm, 20 to 40 feet high, native to northern Brazil. The 8 to 10 leaves are about 9 feet long, with lanceolate shining-green segments, silvery white beneath.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Cuttings, collected in the Hope Gardens, of a hybrid buginvillea (a seedling of B. spectabilis lateritia) with large bracts of a soft rosy-orange color.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Cuttings, collected in the Hope Gardens, of a large erect cactus, said to be a native species and to produce large white nocturnal flowers.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Seeds from a very large fruit of the purple variety served in a hotel at Kingston. The star-apple is a handsome West Indian tree with striking dark-green leaves, copper-colored underneath. The smooth, round, dark-purple fruit is about 3 inches in diameter. When the fruit is ripe, the white jellylike substance surrounding the seed is sweet and agreeable.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plants purchased in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. A small ornamental tree, native to Borneo, with large leaves and very beautiful bright-yellow flowers 2 inches in diameter.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plants purchased in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. A fan palm, native to Sumatra, with a short thick trunk about 4 feet high, a crown of orbicular leaves on petioles 3 to 5 feet long, with linear-lanceolate lobes obliquely truncate at the end.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plant purchased in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. An interesting ornamental tree from west Africa with oblong leaves, sometimes 18 inches in length, and solitary, saucer-shaped axillary flowers, dominantly reddish and bluish, and about 2 inches across; these are borne on the trunk and larger branches.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Seeds collected in Kingston. A graceful cluster palm, 40 to 60 feet high, with spiny stems and equally pinnate leaves about 18 feet long. Native to Ceylon.

crops.presented_by: Col. Robert H. Montgomery and T. A. Fennell
crops.institution_involved: Coconut Grove arboretum and Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: Plants purchased in the Castleton Gardens, Kingston. Variety alba, a form with white flowers.

crops.presented_by: H. O. Albert
crops.description: Tubers presented by H. O. Albert, Brooksville; originally from Hawaii. A strain of the Hawaiian purple-skinned yam (F. P. I. 47446) with nearly pure white flesh instead of the purple-streaked or tinted flesh common in the ordinary form of this yam.
